reviews.review_text: It's a fairly decent open world game, but it has quite a bit of frustrating and unforgiving parts, especially near the end. Well at least it controls better and wasn't-as-frustrating as Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas on the PC.  I'd say ignore this and go for Just Cause 2 instead (Windows ♥♥♥♥♥ta or higher required for DX 10)

Get Just Cause 2 instead. It's basically the same game, except actually finished. This one only has inklings of ideas which were never developed, and simply has no polish whatsoever. For example, take the settlement takeover missions, which are a cool idea and which you'll probably be doing a lot. 'Missions' might be too generous. There's basically only one (shoot enemies, destroy roadblock #1, shoot enemies, destroy roadblock #2, shoot enemies, destroy roadblock #3, rush to flag / kill a specific enemy - the only difference you can spot between them is that when taking over cities you don't have to destroy roablocks), which you will be doing over and over and over and over again. Do you at least get something cool for your troubles? Nope, just a new save point and a color of some pixels flipping on the map. Or take the combat, which you'll be doing a lot of. The game has only two levels of enemy threat. 'Light drizzle' if they are using bullets, 'instagib' if they're using explosives. For your own part, you'll have tiny, hard to see crosshairs (if you play at any real resolution)... or extremely intrusive autoaim which kicks in while you're manning vehicle weapons (which are another cool idea on their own) and which will actually very often prevent you from shooting what you want to shoot (say, the barricade rather than all the random soldiers all over the place). Or take the grappling hook, which is an amazingly fun tool in JC2, and which is an unreliable and unwieldy piece of crap in this game. The whole thing is just extremely rushed and upolished.  Again, just get JC2 instead. I can assure you, you will not miss out on anything by skipping JC1.

I can safely give this game the 'Meh' Seal of Semi-Approval. -- Just Cause is a series about blowing s$#@ up and having fun, and it all started right with this unpolished world of cross-gen mediocrity. Yet, everything wrong with this game somehow works in its favor. It's fairly easy to get lost in the world and start collecting things only to be interrupted by military forces, in which the surprisingly excellent gunplay grants you access to their car and a massive chase sequence that usually involves hilariously bad AI, being absolutely swarmed by enemy vehicles, and lots of stunt jumping. The missions are solid, the voice acting is cringeworthy, and overall the game is somewhat enjoyable as a budget title.  The biggest flaw, however, is its lack of polish and special mechanics. My problem with this game is that I can't help but compare it to its legendary successor, Just Cause 2. I know the hardware was limited and they really did make the most of Xbox/PS2 hardware, but it doesn't change the fact that after so many hours of JC2, the upgrades from game to sequel definitely hurt in trying to go back.  If you have a crappy computer, want some time to kill, or just want to see where this series began, there's a fair chance you might get your moneys' worth here. On any half-decent computer, however, I'd recommend skipping straight to its sequel. JC2 is a damn near perfect game, and there's a reason it outshines its predecessor.

Just Cause.  This game is good, but not memorable. It's an old game, and unfortunately it really shows it. Vehicle driving is far from fun, and while it *might* be better, with it a controller, good luck with that because there's no controller support.  The game also feels rather unbalanced, with the majority of missions being completable with just the primary handguns, due to the fact they have infinite ammo and basically shoot as fast as you can click.  The police are also a huge nusiance, they seem to be nearly aimbot accurate, and pursue you with a fierce passion and seem virtually unescapable, combine that with the unsuable vehicles and police chases are far from fun.  Unless you wanted to experience the first game like me, or are going to get the game as part of a bundle, I'm just not sure I can recommend this game, with the exception of if it goes on sale (which it thankfully does).

Firstly, for it's time this was an ambitious project and would have been impressive. That asside I am reviewing it as it is now, for sale here on Steam.  You play a preset character but there is hardly any example where you exhibit any personality at all so picking a character would hardly effect your experiece.  You start immediately, thrown into the action, which is awkward. You'll find instantly that you have very limited options when disposing of your enemies which is a shame because it has the endlessly funny old ragdoll physics similar to Spiderman 2 and Mercenaries: Playground of Destruction. You need more tools and things to play with for combat, or murder, to be of any interest.  If you're like me you'll do some research on the story as you play as putting things into context is important but the story is not likely to immerse you or entertain you.  With this in mind you will be given a large map to basically capture by yourself. You will have followers that come and go... mostly go as you they try to protect your grenades from loud noises.  There is no real reason to capture the map, it's just pointless busy work - you gain access to better weapons and vehicles but personally it didn't change much for me. You don't have to capture everything, however, you can follow the story (which does have you completing side quests) and you'll get through them without much trouble.  If you must know, should you play Just Cause 2 without playing this you will not miss out. Read up on the game on Google if you wish.  Overall I cannot recommend this game based on what I have played - note that dated graphics/physics don't bother me so long as the mechanics are fun.   Just Cause 1: 3/10 - Ambitious, sometimes fun yet asks too much with far too little.  Recommended alternatives:  Mercenaries: Playground of Destrution - 8/10 Just Cause 2 - 7/10

This was truly a game that got better with the sequels. Aside from that, the side quests are tedious and not worth doing, the travel time from key mission to key mission is mind numbing, and the countless glitches. I'm currently stuck on the second to last level of the game because it's missing key cutscenes. As for other bugs, certain cars with turrets will glitch by rotating uncontrollably and messing with the turning mechanics of the car. I would switch to the rocket mode of the tank, and it hurled me into the sea with its violent rotations - like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ nonsensical helicopter. Also, sometimes when you try to steal someone elses car, the door comes flying off.   The resolution is a minor gripe, but the game is still beautiful for the time that it was in.   Just Cause this game will be cheap as hell, doesn't mean you should buy it. Really - skip this one. You'll save yourself hours of frustration over a plot you don't care about.

Short Review: The game is dated and its age clearly shows. When I first got the game, the user reviews were mostly positive. Now it's mixed, so you can probably tell from that too.   Full Review: - Gameplay & Graphics While the scenes in the video look nice, playing it in 2014 with a 1680 x 1050 resolution and later in 2015 with a 1920 x 1080 resolution makes me feel like crying. If you force the game to full screen, it's pixelated, else it's small. I could adjust my default screen resolution to suit the game, but this simply reinforces that the game is outdated. It may be good in 2006, but certainly not now. The controls are your typical WASD and mouse interaction, while for the gameplay itself, I did not fully explore the game so I cannot offer a full storyline review. However, from my early stages in the game, it takes way too long to travel from one point to another with little to offer. While Far Cry also requires you to walk a long distance, at least you get to hunt some game. Not in Just Cause 1. It's just holding W and hoping someday, you get there.  - Audio The music and sound effects are pretty average in my opinion. I'm not a fan of it, but taste is subjective.  - Verdict Don't buy it, even it's for a really cheap 90% discount. Unless you're using an older and smaller computer, you've played it before and you want to play it again. In that case, follow your desire.

In the standard tradition of Steam Summer Sales reinvigorating Bargain Bin Breakdowns I bring you, Just Cause. I picked up the first two in the series, and their included DLC content for an amount low enough not care what the games were. Having been part of a franchise that I recognized I knew they couldn’t be total crap, right?  Purchased and installed they sat there, icons on the desktop, being ignored while double clicks would happen elsewhere. Two icons over LEGO Worlds gets a double click, on the other side of the screen Quake 4 is the proud recipient of a click followed by and press of ‘Enter’ on the keyboard. Team Fortress 2, Fallout 3, Resident Evil 4, Race to the White House, Minecraft, Chips Challenge, even the Recycling Bin were all getting more click-action. Until I finally decided to hover the cursor atop its icon and give it the grace of the double-click. Why, after all this time did I finally take this step? Just cause.  As of writing I’ve logged five hours playing Just Cause and while that’s not enough time to provide a fair and honest review, I’m gonna do one anyway. Just cause.  Things start off with a free fall from the back of a plane where I need to meet up with a contact on a beach. The first time I did this I opened my parachute earlier than I meant to, then closed it and reopened it again, and again and again, and again. I guess Rico(the main character) has a hundred reserve chutes or maybe he can fold them up and repack them quickly? After a while I just decided to belly flop into the ocean, die, and start this crazy mess over. Only I didn’t die. Falling from really high up, gaining speed by holding my body tight and pointing down and I just splash like it was a five foot high dive.  I stared at the screen for a moment or two, awe struck, slightly annoyed. Seconds went by and I noticed the lack of a breathing reminder. So I waited, and waited, and waited some more. Never did I see anything informing me of a need to exit the water to breath nor did I suffer to the fate of suffocation. I’m going to hope the developers went with this route because of some aspect of the game I haven’t experienced yet, and not just cause.  Once I restarted and made it to the beach proper I helped my contact guy fight off some other people and then we left in his truck. During the truck ride I got to see the auto-aiming performed by the mounted gun in the back of the truck. I’m starting to notice a trend of ‘easy mode’, is this because I’m playing on an easy difficulty? Maybe, I don’t know, but I’m not complaining about it. I’ve reached the point where I’d rather have a enjoyable casual gaming experience than getting worked up because its too much of a challenge.  We make it to the base or hideout, or whatever it is, where I get a cut scene leading me into the first real mission. What that actually is I haven’t a clue since I’m focused on how this guy talking to me is completely trying to be Sam Axe from Burn Notice. But whatever, lets get this pony show on the road. I leave that place check around my surrounding and find a motorcycle, so I hop on and start driving towards the point marked on my map, just cause.  At some point I passed a police car and they yelled “Stop!” and hit the lights/sirens combo. I thought ‘Wow, that’s awesome it detected me speeding, this is going to a fun challenge to play!‘ So I stopped, and the police car pulled up and they got out. I got off my motorcycle, not knowing what to expect, then they shot me. I guess I should have expected this. Although I don’t know what it was that triggered them to attack me, but the police yelling at you constantly is an annoying part of the game, just cause.  I think it was somewhere around here that I realized I was playing a mob-less tropical-island-based Grand Theft Auto. Don’t immediately take that as a bad thing, the GTA franchise is one of the best ones out there. And sure, there are other games out there that put you in an open world like that, Mafia is another that comes to mind. But I mark GTA with that distinction since it was at least the first one I played.  The main story didn’t grab me as I had hoped, I went and broke some guy out of prison and instead of him wondering why I would do that having never met me, he had me join him. Which was good, since the reason why I was to break him out was so I trick him into letting me join his group. I feel like the leader of a rebel group would question the guy he’s never met before that breaks him out of prison. I guess he decided to just cause.  I did a couple main story line missions before I discovered the side missions. Missions where you help liberate small villages from different armies or something. Those were fun, repetitive, but fun. You would basically work your way up a road taking out roadblocks along the way until you reached either a flag that needed capturing or a leader that needed killing. I would fly my helicopter to a mission marked on the map, liberate the town, and then steal the helicopter parked on the roof of the building. Then fly off to the next one. I did this for a couple hours, and I had more fun than I had playing the main storyline. I’m not trashing the story or anything, it just didn’t grab me like liberation missions did.  From what I’ve seen Just Cause is the child of Far Cry and Grand Theft Auto’s wild night in Vegas. They’ve taken pieces from both and created this whole new thing. Its not terrible, its not amazing, it just is, just cause.

It might have been okay for it's time...but it's nowhere near the GTA series...even of the time. I found myself disinterested in the world and the game is too 'random'. AKA if you look away from a car on the road and turn your back again the car will be gone or replaced. This applies to vehicles that are being driven on the road too. The game play is pretty repetitive as well but fortunately you dont have to do the repetitive missions to progress the story (unlike in Just Cause 2). So you can beat it and get it over with reaaaaally fast.

This is the second game in a row I have failed to finish. This game started off very well, it has a bright colourful cartoony style and nice music. There's a huge environment to explore with loads of side missions. It has some zany grappling gun mechanics where you can leap between vehicles. So where do the problems lie? Firstly the side missions seem rather repetitive and the rewards aren't that appealing. Certain weapons look very similar making finding good guns difficult. Getting around can be annoying, roads are few and far between with massive cliffs and dense woodlands covering most the islands. They have included airlifts and vehicle drops but these take an annoyingly long time. The vehicles' handling is very light at speed to make getting anywhere even more frustrating. The main reason I never finished this game is the last missions are just really hard with swarms of constantly spawning bad guys and after failing repeatedly I thought I have better things to do with my time.
Played on Xbox and while decent for it's time, it does look very dated. Decent open-world but seems lifeless. Just Cause 2 is the better game to go straight into.
